discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The correct answer is:

B. port scanning

Explanation:
A port scanning attack is characterized by sending packets (often a single SYN packet) to multiple ports on a target machine to determine which ports are open, closed, or filtered. This behavior aligns with the scenario described, where a single SYN packet is sent to each port.

Why not D. SYN flood
A SYN flood attack involves sending numerous SYN packets to a specific port to overwhelm the target, which is different from the described behavior of targeting multiple ports with single packets.

Selected Answer: B
A single SYN packet sent to each port, is indicative of port scanning. Answer B.

questions.question_text: After a large influx of network traffic to externally facing devices, a security engineer begins investigating what appears to be a denial of service attack. When the packet capture data is reviewed, the engineer notices that the traffic is a single SYN packet to each port. Which type of attack is occurring?
What is the dataflow set in the NetFlow flow-record format?

choices.B: Dataflow set provides basic information about the packet, such as the NetFlow version.
choices.C: Dataflow set is a collection of binary patterns.
choices.D: Dataflow set is a collection of data records.
choices.A: Dataflow set is a collection of HEX records.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Data FlowSet-a data FlowSet is a collection of one or more data records that have been grouped together in an export packet. Data record-A data record provides information about an IP flow that exists on the device that produced an export packet.

Selected Answer: B
By the book: Attack Complexity (AC) measures the difficulty of exploitation, with Low (L) requiring no special conditions and High (H) needing specific preconditions. This metric indicates conditions beyond the attackerâ€™s control that must exist in order to exploit the vulnerability. 
Answer B is correct.

Selected Answer: C
Looks like C to me

questions.question_text: According to CVSS, what is attack complexity?

choices.D: number of patches available for certain attack mitigation and how complex the workarounds are
choices.A: existing exploits available in the wild exploiting the vulnerability
choices.C: number of actions an attacker should perform to exploit the vulnerability
choices.B: existing circumstances beyond the attacker's control to exploit the vulnerability
The threat actor gained access to the system by known credentials.
choices.A: The threat actor used a dictionary-based password attack to obtain credentials.
choices.C: The threat actor used the teardrop technique to confuse and crash login services.
choices.D: The threat actor used an unknown vulnerability of the operating system that went undetected.

questions.question_text: An employee reports that someone has logged into their system and made unapproved changes, files are out of order, and several documents have been placed in the recycle bin. The security specialist reviewed the system logs, found nothing suspicious, and was not able to determine what occurred. The software is up to date; there are no alerts from antivirus and no failed login attempts. What is causing the lack of data visibility needed to detect the attack?

discussion.content: B. The threat actor gained access to the system by known credentials.
I think 'B' because if the threat actor know the right credential he can also delete logs file and seem to be never entered in to the system

the question stated clearly that the suspicious activity "made unapproved changes, files are out of order, and several documents have been placed in the recycle bin." If the attacker used known credentials, then this will appear in the system logs under that credential. I am going with answer D

Selected Answer: B
If the attacker used valid credentials to access the employee's system, it would explain why there were no failed login attempts in the logs, and why there were no alerts from antivirus. In this scenario, the attacker would not need to use a dictionary-based password attack to obtain credentials or exploit an unknown vulnerability in the operating system.

The fact that the security specialist found nothing suspicious in the system logs could also suggest that the attacker used legitimate credentials to access the system, making it difficult to detect the attack through traditional security monitoring methods.

Selected Answer: B
B is the correct answer for me.

Certification exams are always tricky. Cisco wants you to overthink. So, I always go for the simplest but sensible answer during an exam.
I guess CIsco believes B to be the right answer

D IS CORRECT
ZERO DAY ATTACK

The simplest is almost always the right answer.
Think of the real world.
An user complaining this: two options: a cat on the keyboard (I know because I have one) or another person/bot with user credentials.

comments.content: I agree with this, certification exams are always tricky. Cisco wants you to overthink. So, I always go for the simplest but sensible answer during an exam.

discussion.content: A lot of these questions are horrible and could go either way in my opinion. I really hate the way these certs word questions and answers
I think answer is D - zero day exploit

comments.content:
But it says in the question the engineer investigated the system logs, so if any logins where done with known credentials it would show up in there. So only conclusion can be that the attacker used an unknown way of entry which isn't captured in the system logs and monitoring software.
So I agree D should be the right answer.

the question stated clearly that the suspicious activity "made unapproved changes, files are out of order, and several documents have been placed in the recycle bin." If the attacker used known credentials, then this will appear in the system logs under that credential. I am going with answer D

the question says "The security specialist reviewed the system logs, found nothing suspicious, and was not able to determine what occurred. The software is up to date; there are no alerts from antivirus and no failed login attempts." which means that a successful login with known credentials would have been ignored as valid system usage, and not dinspected as malicious. I believe the Given answer of _"KNOWN CREDENTIALS" is the correct answer
Zero day exploits can give you access... but not always undetected.... unless you're already know the credentials

questions.question_text: What are two differences in how tampered and untampered disk images affect a security incident? (Choose two.)

comments.content: Tampered images may have been modified or altered in a way that changes their content or meaning.

choices.C: The image is tampered if the stored hash and the computed hash match.
choices.E: The image is untampered if the stored hash and the computed hash match.
choices.D: Untampered images are used in the security investigation process.
choices.B: Tampered images are used in the incident recovery process.
choices.A: Tampered images are used in the security investigation process.
